title: 108_hr1814
content: The Act titled "Naturalization and Family Protection for Military Members Act of 2003" outlines requirements for naturalization through service in the Armed Forces of the United States. The Act "Naturalization and Family Protection for Military Members Act of 2003" reduces the required service period for naturalization from three years to two years and prohibits the imposition of fees for filing a petition for naturalization. The Act "Naturalization and Family Protection for Military Members Act of 2003" reduces the required service period for naturalization from three years to two years and prohibits charging fees for filing a petition for naturalization or the issuance of a certificate of naturalization. No fee shall be charged from the applicant for these services. The Act "Naturalization and Family Protection for Military Members Act of 2003" reduces the required service period for naturalization from three years to two years and prohibits charging fees for filing a petition for naturalization or the issuance of a certificate of naturalization. No fee shall be charged from the applicant for these services. The Secretaries of Homeland Security, State, and Defense must ensure that naturalization proceedings for members of the Armed Forces overseas are available. Members of the Armed Forces can access services through US embassies, consulates, and military installations overseas. A technical amendment replaces "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security" in the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 3 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide naturalization benefits for members of the Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve. SEC. 4 extends posthumous benefits to surviving spouses, children, and parents. SEC. 3 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide naturalization benefits for members of the Selected Reserve of the Ready Reserve. Specifically, it allows the spouse of a deceased U.S. citizen who served in the military and died as a result of service-related injury or disease to remain an immediate relative for immigration purposes if they file a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. The amendment allows the spouse of a deceased U.S. citizen who served in the military and died as a result of service-related injury or disease to remain an immediate relative for immigration purposes if they file a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. Additionally, children of such citizens are also considered immediate relatives under certain conditions. The amendment allows the spouse of a deceased U.S. citizen to remain an immediate relative if they file a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. The alien must file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendment allows the parent of a deceased U.S. citizen who served in the military to remain an immediate relative by filing a petition within 2 years of the citizen's death. The amendment allows a deceased U.S. citizen's parent to file a petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security for classification under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The citizen's parent does not have to be 21 years old for a parent to benefit under this provision. Applications for Adjustment of Status by Surviving Spouses, Children, and Parents are allowed for aliens who were related to a deceased military member and applied before the death occurred. The alien must have served in the U.S. military, died due to service-related causes, and been granted posthumous citizenship. Posthumous citizenship can be granted under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Spouses and children of lawful permanent resident aliens can be considered immediate relatives and eligible for certain benefits if included in a petition for family-sponsored immigrant classification. Spouses and children of lawful permanent resident aliens can file petitions for classification under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act for benefits like deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. Spouses or children of lawful permanent resident aliens can file petitions under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act to be eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization if certain criteria are met, including serving in the military and being granted posthumous citizenship. Parents of lawful permanent resident aliens can file a petition under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act if the parent served honorably in the military, air, or naval forces of the United States. This allows them to be eligible for deferred action, advance parole, and work authorization. An alien physically present in the United States who is the beneficiary of a petition under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act may apply for adjustment of status to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. In determining the admissibility of an alien receiving an immigration benefit, certain grounds of inadmissibility do not apply. Amendments are made to sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding benefits to survivors and technical and conforming changes. Amendments are made to sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding benefits to survivors, including changes to the definition of a surviving spouse. The Act and its amendments will be effective as of September 11, 2001.
